title: Introduction
body:
Adapt allows you to combine Text and Graphic components on the scrolling page to create rich and varied learning experiences. In addition, a wide range of interactive components are also available to help encourage deeper engagement with the material.

These presentation components can be structured in any way to help you create learning experiences that meet the needs of your learners.

In addition, if your course is being launched from an LMS or LRS, you can personalise the course content by having the learners name dynamically displayed in the body, instruction or feedback text.
instruction: {{_globals._learnerInfo.firstname}}, scroll down to see what presentation components are available as part of the core bundle.

title: Text
body:
The simple Text component can often be the best choice for imparting information, particularly when used in conjunction with complementary graphics. In this example we’ve used the Blank component to the right to create a window through to the block background.

Remember, content doesn’t always warrant an interaction so less can often be really be more. Instead, look to intersperse more interactive components with text and graphics where they add the maximum value.

Component can either be single or spanned.

title: Graphic
body:
This is the Graphic component body. You can introduce your graphic or you may just want to let the graphics do the talking.

Component can either be single or spanned.

title: Narrative
body:
The Narrative component lets you scroll through a series of images each with some accompanying text.

This component is always spanned.
instruction: Select the next and back arrows to find out more.
mobileInstruction: Select the plus icon followed by the next arrow to find out more.

_items.title: Narrative item 1
_items.body: Narratives are particularly good for showing dialogue between two or more characters, with each step of the conversation being accompanied by an image. This photo story approach can be used to provide context for the learning to follow, to illustrate real-world application of the learning or to show the impact on people when the learning hasn’t been applied correctly.

_items.title: Narrative item 2
_items.body: It can also be used to present case studies, where the different displays are used to set the scene, show the key events and then the outcome.

_items.title: Narrative item 3
_items.body: This component can also be useful when you want to illustrate the constituent steps that make up a larger process.

title: Hot Graphic
body:
You can add interactivity to an image by using the Hot Graphic. This component allows you to position icons over an image. When an icon is selected, content associated with its corresponding location is displayed in a window over the image. This component will fall back to a Narrative when viewed on mobile.

This component is always spanned and should be set to a ratio of 884 x 491 .
instruction: Select the icons to find out more.
mobileInstruction: Select the plus icon followed by the next arrow to find out more.

_items.title: Hot Graphic item 1
_items.body: This is display text associated with item 1.

_items.title: Hot Graphic item 2
_items.body: This is display text associated with item 2.

_items.title: Hot Graphic item 3
_items.body: This is display text associated with item 3.

title: Media
body:
Sometimes we need to make use of rich media to really drive home a point, bring a complex subject to life or simply use audio to literally do the talking. This is when the Media component comes to the fore.

Component can be either single or spanned.
instruction: Select the play button to start the video.

_transcript.inlineTranscriptBody: Responsive design means you can create a course once but view it on a wide range of browsers, devices or operating systems. This is achieved by using fluid layouts to ensure the presentation of content is tailored to suit the size of the screen. This means you can start a course on your laptop and finish it later on your mobile or tablet. We call it Adapt

title: Accordion
body:
You can use the Accordion component to present learners with a series of headings which, once selected, expand to reveal associated text. Select each of the headings below to find out more about how accordions can be used.

These components can be either single or spanned. If spanned they can also contain a graphic.
instruction: Select the headings to find out more.

_items.title: Lists
_items.body:
This is display text 1 and we’re using it to discuss lists.

If you need to present a list that can stand alone as a piece of content, but which can also be explored in more detail, accordions are a great choice.

_items.title: Steps in a process
_items.body:
This is display text 2 and now we’re discussing how accordions can be great at presenting a process.

The headings can be used to present the high-level stages in the process, which once selected, provide a more extensive explanation of what happens at that specific point.

_items.title: Recaps
_items.body:
This is display text 3 and we’re now talking about using accordions to provide the learner with a summary.

Each accordion item corresponds to a key piece of learning presented on the page. When this item is selected a short summary of the learning point is provided.

title: Multiple Choice Question
body: In what year was the first recorded instance of a large scale assessment that consists solely of multiple choice questions?
instruction: Choose one option and select Submit.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
Correct feedback text.

That’s correct. The first large assessment to consist solely of the multiple choice question type was the Army Alpha test, used from 1917 to evaluate U.S. military recruits in the First World War.

Source: Wikipedia

Component facts: Multiple Choice Questions (or MCQs) are a tried and tested method for presenting learners with a simple text-based question. Component is either single or spanned.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect feedback text.

That’s not right. The first large assessment to consist solely of the multiple choice question type was the Army Alpha test, used from 1917 to evaluate U.S. military recruits in the First World War.

Source: Wikipedia

Component facts: Multiple Choice Questions (or MCQs) are a tried and tested method for presenting learners with a simple text-based question. Component is either single or spanned.

title: Graphical Multiple Choice Question
body: The Graphical Multiple Choice Question is an alternative to the standard MCQ, and allows you to ask a question and present the options as graphics (with accompanying captions). This component is always spanned.
instruction: Choose option 2 and select Submit.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
Correct feedback text.

That’s correct. Option 2 is what we were looking for!

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect feedback text.

Sorry, that’s not right. In fact Option 2 is what we were looking for (the clue was in the instruction text!).

title: Text Input
body: Can you name one of the three companies that established Adapt as a community-led open source project?
instruction: Input your answer and select Submit.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
Correct answer feedback.

That’s correct. The Adapt open source project was established by Kineo, Learning Pool and Sponge. At the time of writing, there are a total of nine official collaborators.

Component facts: Text input components let learners enter their own answers, which is great for questions that require a bit more flexibility, like those with answers that could be written as both full words and numbers.

_partlyCorrect.final:
Partially correct answer feedback.

That’s partially correct. The Adapt open source project was established by Kineo, Learning Pool and Sponge. At the time of writing, there are a total of nine official collaborators.

Component facts: Text input components let learners enter their own answers, which is great for questions that require a bit more flexibility, like those with answers that could be written as both full words and numbers.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect answer feedback.

Sorry, that’s not right. The Adapt open source project was established by Kineo, Learning Pool and Sponge. At the time of writing, there are a total of nine official collaborators.

Component facts: Text input components let learners enter their own answers, which is great for questions that require a bit more flexibility, like those with answers that could be written as both full words and numbers.

title: Matching
body: Can you identify some of the key facts and figures associated with the Adapt Open Source project?
instruction: Choose an option from each dropdown list and select Submit.

_items.text: The Adapt Open Source project was formed in:
Adapt adheres to level AA of the <abbr title=Web Content Accessibility Guidelines>WCAG</abbr> version 2, but when were these published?
Which of these languages would benefit from using the recent addition of Right To Left (RTL) language support within Adapt?

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
Correct answer feedback.

Yes, that’s right. Adapt was established as an Open Source project in 2013. The Web Accessibility Initiative (WAI) published the WCAG 2.0 guidelines in 2008 and Hebrew is the only language of the four shown which reads right to left.

Component facts: The Matching component lets you match a series of questions or statements with the corresponding options from the dropdown box. Component is either single or spanned.

_partlyCorrect.final:
Partially correct answer feedback.

That’s partially correct. Adapt was established as an Open Source project in 2013. The Web Accessibility Initiative (WAI) published the WCAG 2.0 guidelines in 2008 and Hebrew is the only language of the four shown which reads right to left.

Component facts: The Matching component lets you match a series of questions or statements with the corresponding options from the dropdown box. Component is either single or spanned.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect answer feedback.

Sorry, that’s not right. Adapt was established as an Open Source project in 2013. The Web Accessibility Initiative (WAI) published the WCAG 2.0 guidelines in 2008 and Hebrew is the only language of the four shown which reads right to left.

Component facts: The Matching component lets you match a series of questions or statements with the corresponding options from the dropdown box. Component is either single or spanned.

title: Slider
body: Working memory is thought to be responsible for our ability to temporarily hold and manipulate information, but according to a paper by Miller (1956) what ‘magic number’ describes its capacity?
instruction: Drag the slider to make your choice and select Submit.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
Correct answer feedback.

Yes, that’s right. According to Miller’s paper 7 +/- 2 chunks of information was the limited capacity of working memory. Various theories from the field of cognitive psychology such as Miller’s magical number, chunking, the forgetting curve and spaced repetition have all influenced learning theory over the last 50 years or so.

Component facts: The correct answer for a Slider component can be an exact number or a range. In this instance we have set the correct answer to a range of 5-9 due to the correct answer being seven plus or minus two. Component is either single or spanned.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect answer feedback.

Sorry, that’s not right. According to Miller’s paper 7 +/- 2 chunks of information was the limited capacity of working memory. Various theories from the field of cognitive psychology such as Miller’s magical number, chunking, the forgetting curve and spaced repetition have all influenced learning theory over the last 50 years or so.

Component facts: The correct answer for a Slider component can be an exact number or a range. In this instance we have set the correct answer to a range of 5-9 due to the correct answer being seven plus or minus two. Component is either single or spanned.

title: To scroll or not to scroll?
displayTitle: To scroll or not to scroll?
body: Can you identify a few of the benefits that a vertical scrolling approach offers over the traditional back and next approach?
instruction: Choose one or more options and select Submit.

_items.text: Scrolling is common place on the web and therefore familiar to the learner
Scrolling reduces the need for unnecessary navigation as pages can be as long (or as short) as they need to be
Scrolling helps ensure designs are more mobile friendly
Scrolling means you no longer need to first gain learners attention

title: Control the scroll
body: The Trickle extension makes it possible to control how the learner scrolls down the page, but what elements of a page can it be applied to?

title: Scoring bands
body:
The Assessment Results component allows you to specify the assessment pass mark, and provide tailored feedback to as many scoring bands as you wish.

In this short assessment we set the pass mark at 75% or above and provided four scoring bands, each of which has some accompanying feedback. The four scoring bands were:

  • 0-49% (fail)
  • 50-74% (fail)
  • 75-99% (pass)
  • 100% (perfect score)

So, how did you do? Let’s find out.

_bands.feedback:
You didn’t pass, achieving a score of {{scoreAsPercent}}%.

You didn’t do so well in the Adapt assessment demo, but don’t worry. There’s lots of information about the Adapt basics on our site. We’d also suggest you pay a visit to the forum or chat room and ask our ever-helpful community to answer any questions that you might have.

You didn’t pass, achieving a score of {{scoreAsPercent}}%.

You already know some of the Adapt basics but please explore our site for more information. Also pay a visit to the forum or chat room and ask our ever-helpful community to answer any questions that you might have.

You passed, achieving a score of {{scoreAsPercent}}%.

You’re clearly already pretty knowledgeable about Adapt so, if you haven’t already, please consider sharing your expertise on the Adapt community forums.

You passed, achieving a score of {{scoreAsPercent}}%.

You’re clearly already a black belt in Adapt! If you haven’t already, please consider sharing your expertise on the Adapt community forums.

title: Presentation Components
body:
Presentation components are not assessed. They are there solely to display information to the learner.

The current presentation components in use are:

  • Text
  • Graphic
  • Narrative
  • Hot Graphic
  • Media
  • Accordion

title: Question Components Text heading
body:
This module showcases all the stable question components that can be found in Adapt.

We will cover:

  • Multiple Choice Questions
  • Graphical Multiple Choice Questions
  • Matching
  • Slider
  • Test Input

title: Assessment Components
body:
Assessment components allow us to track a learners progress, they allow us to display a score to the user and send their progress to any SCORM or xAPI/TinCan LRS. This module will showcase a variety of extensions and components, including:

  • Tutor
  • Assessment Results
  • Assessment

This module has a quiz which will test your knowledge of the Adapt Framework structure.

title: Beta Components
body: These components are still in testing/need fixing

title: Using Adapt at the ODI
body:
This is a short module introducing you to some of the basics of Adapt. It will provide you with some handy information on how to use Adapt within the context of the ODIs own customisations.

This module should teach you how to...

  • Think about your audience
  • Refine your style
  • Design and structure an Adapt module
  • Use themes
  • Deploy a course

title: Refining your audience and topic
body:
The first thing you need to decide is your audience. This may be given to you in a brief by a client, or you may need to define your audience yourself. Think about what your audience wants or needs to learn about. It can be useful to write a concept note to help you answer some key questions.

With learning, less can be more. You might find that your topic is too broad to fit into one module and would be better split into multiple modules. The adapt framework lets you link modules together.

title: Designing your outcomes and structure
body: Contrary to popular belief, the next stage of designing learning is not writing the content, but designing the structure. Planning the structure and outcomes of your learning makes it easier to check that your content has a logical flow.

_items.body:
Outcome-led learning is where you identify what your learners need to learn before you start. These are commonly called learning outcomes or learning objectives.

Content-led learning (learning where the content is decided before the structure or outcome) leads to surface learning. Outcome led learning leads to deep learning. To find out more about these concepts and how they relate to levels of teaching, take a look at this video.

Writing outcomes can be quite challenging at the beginning. Try to think of them as the headings that you want.

List the headings at the beginning to guide your learners -  these can be framed as questions, or simply as bullet points.
_items.title: Outcomes

_items.body:
You should include the outcomes you've written in the bullet points at the beginning of each module. Your structure should signpost your learners and let them know what they are going to learn next.

Each outcome should match to a block and a question.

Each block should build on the last. You can think of it like steps to reach a goal.
_items.title: Structure

instruction: Click on the headings below to explore more

title: Including content and case studies
body:
Once the structure and outcomes are in place, the next thing to look at is the content itself. The content needs to be relevant to both the audience and the topic, so keep both in mind when you're writing. 

Content needs to match the block heading and the tick at the top (the outcome). Make sure that you include the key information that you want them to learn

Be strict with yourself: if the content doesn't match the headings and/or the ticks, take another look at the structure. It might be that the structure needs refining, but it also might be that the content doesn't have a logical flow. This is also known as alignment. For many people, alignment is the most challenging part of designing learning and it can be frustrating to realise that what you have designed isn't working because it isn't aligned.

Including relevant case studies and examples to back up your content will help your learners. Adult learners in particular need to be able to see how what they are learning is relevant to them and their work. One great thing about online learning is that you can hyperlink to the examples and case studies that you've used, so that your learners can verify what they are learning. Including links is also good for 'deep learners' who want to take their learning to the next level and explore more in the subject area.

title: Refining your style
body: Every individual has his or her own style of designing and delivering learning. Below, we explore some ways to avoid some common traps and create a suitable environment for your learners to learn at their own pace.

_items.body:
The aim of writing eLearning is to create a suitable environment for your learners to learn at their own pace.

It should not be a chance for you to demonstrate sophisticated writing techniques, complex language or complicated sentence structures.

Using easy words and short sentences will help your learners learn the key information and will ensure they aren't distracted by added noise.
_items.title: Avoid complex language

_items.body:
Key terms are concepts that will be used throughout the eLearning. 

It is important to make sure that learners can define the key terms at the beginning of any lesson, whether online or in the classroom. They will be unable to successfully continue their learning if they cannot define the basic concepts.

Often, the first outcome in an eLearning module will be for learners to define key terms. For example, the first block in this open data and agriculture module is devoted to defining data and open data.

However, not all concepts are important for learners. Once again, ask yourself what your learners need to learn in order to complete the module. Try to avoid too many complex terms, as people can only learn x in x, and you don't want them to remember complex concepts and nothing else!
_items.title: Define key terms

_items.body:
Most types of writing require the writer to use synonyms to vary the language and terms used in the text. 

For learning, repetition is key. Repetition reinforces learning and makes key information stay at the forefront of the learner's mind.

Try to avoid synonyms, particularly for your key terms. Very few words mean exactly the same thing. For example, you could argue that the 'value of open data' and the 'impact of open data' are synonymous and yet they have slightly different meanings.
_items.title: Repetition

_items.body: Using pictures can be a great way to help reinforce learning, particularly for visual learners. Engaging visuals that are related to the content will help learners. However, pictures can also be distracting, particularly if they are unrelated, jarring or offensive. Try to be consistent with the pictures that you use within a module.
_items.title: Look and feel

instruction: Click on the headings below to explore more

title: Writing questions
body:
Questions are a useful way for learners to test their learning. Not every eLearning module has to include questions, but it is recommended.

When designing questions, take another look at your outcomes and your structure. You should generally have a question per block which should align to an outcome. There are times when you can combine two blocks into one question.

Make sure that the answer to the question is in the block that that question relates to. Using the same text is fine, as for learning repetition is key. The aim of eLearning is for your learners to learn, not for you to trick them with complex questions and multiple answers.

In Adapt you can give learners feedback. Using the same text as appears in the original learning will help them to remember the answer, even if they got the question wrong.

Repeating the picture that you used in the original block will also help visual learners.

title: Are you ready to develop eLearning?
displayTitle: Are you ready to develop eLearning?

title: Best practice guidelines
body: Which of the following should you do?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Repeating key phrases, defining key terms, linking to relevant case studies and examples and checking that your content aligns to your structure will improve the quality of your eLearning and enhance your learners' experience.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Repeating key phrases, defining key terms, linking to relevant case studies and examples and checking that your content aligns to your structure will improve the quality of your eLearning and enhance your learners' experience.

_items.text: Use complex terminology without explaining it
Use offensive pictures to shock your learners into learning
Link to relevant case studies and examples
Check your content aligns to your structure

instruction: Choose FOUR answers, then click Submit

title: Summary
body:
Developing eLearning is not as straightforward as uploading powerpoints and talking heads to a website.

In this module we have explored some of the key elements in designing quality eLearning. However, these are guidelines and there may be better ways for your purpose. We recommend that you explore to find your own best practices. Why not share them back with the Adapt community?

If you want to find out more, take a look at these resources:

  • Learning outcomes (also called learning objectives or LOs), specifically Bloom's taxonomy
  • Learning styles, particularly VAK/VARK and Honey and Mumford
  • Deep and surface learning

title: Getting started with Adapt eLearning
body:
Adapt eLearning is a multi-award winning tool for developing engaging and advanced eLearning.

You are using one of the modules right now!

In this module we are going to explain how an Adapt eLearning page is structured and how you can develop engaging eLearning using the tool.

In this module will cover:

  • The ABC of Adapt
  • Adapt authoring tool
  • Structuring a course
  • Using themes
  • Deploying your course
  • Adapt plugins
  • Getting help

title: The ABC of Adapt
body:
Adapt has a hierarchical layout consisting of pages, articles, blocks and components.

Taking the lead from modern web design, these objects form scrolling pages that present information in a responsible and cross device compatible way allowing people to learn with just a swipe of a finger or thumb.

_items.body: Pages are how the main learning content is presented (similar to a page on the web), and can contain a number of sub-elements, making them perfect to present a single topic in an eLearning course.
_items.title: Pages

_items.body:
Articles are the next step down, and are used to present compound pieces of information within the page. Like pages, articles can be formed of many sub-elements. Articles can also be used to split up a page for presentation purposes.

Typically articles are used to split an assessment section from the main content.

This page contains three articles (all labelled). Although an article can have a title and content, it is advisable to keep all content in components only, leaving articles and blocks to manage layout and style.
_items.title: Articles

_items.body:
Blocks have replaced the traditional screens/slides found in most eLearning publishing software, and present small chunks of related content using components.

In this block (labelled) we have two components (an accordion and a graphic). The block keeps the two together, maintaining the relation. 

Here the block also has a style applied to take a background colour in order to clearly divide the different blocks.
_items.title: Blocks

_items.body:
Components are the main interactions in Adapt, and present simple ideas. Components can be used in a block full-width, or combined with another component for more variety.

Find out more about all the different components, including question components via the Adapt 2.0 demonstration. 

You can also develop your own bespoke components by following the component development guide.
_items.title: Components

title: Adapt authoring tool
body:
In order to get started with building courses in Adapt it is highly recommended that an instance of the authoring tool is setup and supported with regular updates.

A guide on how to set up the authoring tool can be found here.

There are also providers of commercial instances of the authoring tool if you don't want to set up your own instance. 

Once you are setup with the authoring tool you can use this to graphically create courses containing pages, articles, blocks and components.

title: Structuring a course
body:
The majority of courses developed in Adapt eLearning will consist of multiple pages (modules) that form one course. By default the authoring tool will use the default theme and the box menu to give learners a clear way to navigate throughout the course. You can of course customise these with your own menu design and theme, however this needs to be done in code. 

If you wish to develop a course with a single page (or disable the menu) then you can use the start controller, available from the project settings menu of a course.

title: Using themes
body:
Adapt comes with a default (Vanilla) theme as used on the demo site which also has a customisation guide. 

The Open Data Institute (in collaboration with SpongeUK) developed a custom theme for the Caribbean Open Institute that makes blocks stand out and allows quick setting of colors of blocks and components. This theme is also fully responsive to mobile devices and screen widths. If you can, resize this module to see how it responds and changes the layout of components. 

The source code for the CSD theme can be downloaded (as a zip) from the ODI's GitHub. You can then upload the theme directly into the authoring tool using the plugin manager. 

The theme contains 10 color classes "color-one" to "color-ten" which when applied to the class field in the settings of a block will apply that color to the block component parts. If you wish the block background to be the color specified with content in white then add the "inverted" class as well as the color. The theme contains a color palette picture for reference as well as a README with more instructions. 

In this course we have used color-one and color-two with every other block inverted.

title: Deploying your course
body:
By default, the download button in the authoring tool will export a version of the course which can be simply hosted on a web server for people to access.

However extensions can be used to make this exported object into a SCORM 1.2 compliant object for importing into a Learning Management System (LMS). Extensions also add key functionality to your course. 

Explore the different extensions below:

_items.body:
This page allows uses to get a visual indication of their progress through a page as well as provide a fast navigation path on a page. 

Not that this extension is enabled by default on all components. We recommend only leaving it enabled for components that have titles.
_items.title: Page Level Progress

_items.body: The tutor extension provides a basic feedback overlay for question components. Without it the feedback simply won't show.
_items.title: Tutor

_items.body: Trickle is a vertical locking extension which prevents the learning from scrolling until all the previous components are complete.
_items.title: Trickle

_items.body: Enables the user to resume from their last known point when they reload/restart the learning.
_items.title: Bookmarking

_items.body:
This is the core SCORM extension that enables the output of SCORM 1.2 compliant learning objects.

The SCORM 1.2 standard is a widely adopted standard for tracking of a users learning within a Learning Management System. While some aspects of SCORM are mandatory, different LMS platforms require different configurations of the SCORM plugin.

In order to successful deploy the SCORM plugin will involve the input of the LMS administrator to specify the required and supported configuration in Adapt.
_items.title: Spoor

_items.body:
An extension which attaches to an article object to group various question components and provide a score with feedback.

If you are expecting your LMS to receive an attainment score then you will need to enable this extension and configure it for every article in our course that contains an assessment.
_items.title: Assessment

title: Adapt plugins
body:
The following parts of the Adapt eLearning framework can be customised with user contributed plugins and versions:

  • Menus
  • Themes
  • Extensions
  • Components

There is a community plugin registry where plugins can be simply downloaded from and added to the authoring tool. 

Additionally you can choose to develop your own plugins following the many guides available on the wiki.

To find out more about the Adapt framework and authoring tool developments and roadmaps you can refer to their respective open Github repositories.

title: Getting help
body:
The Adapt community is a open community. All their source code, roadmaps and latest developments are open. This means that you get complete visibility on the tool and its future. 

Additionally you can connect to the community in many ways:

_items.body: The Adapt wiki is the most up to date place to find documentation and general guides.
_items.title: The Adapt wiki

_items.body:
A key part of the plugins in adapt is the associated documentation. Each plugin will have it's own associate Github repository which will contain a README.md to help you find out about how to use and configure each. 

For example:

  • Accordion component
  • Graphical multiple choice question

Additionally you can find out the latest developments in each plugin this way.
_items.title: Adapt source code

_items.body: The adapt community forums and mailing lists are a great way to get help and find answers to questions that might have already been asked.
_items.title: Adapt forum and mailing list

_items.body:
The core developers of Adapt use the open Gitter platform for discussing and managing the roadmap. 

If you are wanting to expand the core or develop a specific plugin you can find them online here.
_items.title: Developers discussion channels

title: Q: The ABC of Adapt
body: In which of the presentation elements of Adapt should you place your main learning content?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Components should contain the main learning content (text and images) to be displayed to your learner. Articles and blocks are used to arrange the learning into logical sequences.

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Components should contain the main learning content (text and images) to be displayed to your learner. Articles and blocks are used to arrange the learning into logical sequences.

instruction: Select your answer and click submit

title: Q: Using themes
body: When using the ODIs custom theme, which presentation element in Adapt do you add the “color-ten” style to in order to change the colour of presented content?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Blocks are like the slides in a presentation. However as Adapt provides an infinite scroll experience, coloring blocks different colors helps break up content as slides do.

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Blocks are like the slides in a presentation. However as Adapt provides an infinite scroll experience, colouring blocks different colours helps break up content as slides do.

instruction: Select you answer and click submit

title: Q: Deploying your course
body: If you wish to deploy your course inside a SCORM compliant Learning Management System which two extensions need to be added to your course?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

To make an engaging course you might need them all, however Spoor is essential for deployment in a SCORM compliant Learning Management System (LMS). Assessment is required if your course contains questions of which you want the learners score reported to the LMS.

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

To make an engaging course you might need them all, however Spoor is essential for deployment in a SCORM compliant Learning Management System (LMS). Assessment is required if your course contains questions of which you want the learners score reported to the LMS.

instruction: Select your answer and click submit

title: Q: Adapt plugins
body: Which of the follow are parts of the Adapt framework that can be customised with plugins?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

All the key visual elements (menus, themes and components) can be custom designed as plugins. In addition extensions, including reporting extensions like Spoor, are also plugins allowing the customisation of a course's behaviour.

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

All the key visual elements (menus, themes and components) can be custom designed as plugins. In addition extensions, including reporting extensions like Spoor, are also plugins allowing the customisation of a course's behaviour.

instruction: Select all answers you think are correct and press submit

title: Summary
body:
At the end of each page, it is useful to include a summary. This should be where you draw out key messages again.

In the COI theme add the classes 'inverted footer' to the block in order to turn it the dark grey. Again this separates it visually from the rest of the content.

So there we have it. Get to know your ABC (of Adapt) and you too can create great courses. The biggest challenge is getting the content right so that learners learn.

To finish, the footer below is also part of the theme, ensuring it is included on every page.
